I enjoy articles like Hartley Charlton‚Äôs ‚ÄúMicrosoft Edge Looks Set to Overtake Safari as World‚Äôs Second Most Popular Desktop Browser.‚Äù It‚Äôs juicy! We know these massive players in the browser market care very much about their market share, so when ‚Ä¶

Web Component Pseudo-Classes and Pseudo-Elements are Easier Than You Think originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
A fun deep dive from Zach. Do you have an opinion on which you should use?
1) https://website.com/foo/
2) https://websites.com/foo
The first option has a ‚Äútrailing slash.‚Äù The second does not.
I‚Äôve always preferred this thinking: you use a trailing ‚Ä¶
Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled? originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled?

Let me demonstrate the usefulness of ‚Ä¶
When to Avoid the text-decoration Shorthand Property originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.description:

Manuel Matuzovic‚Äôs CSS Specificity Demo originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

In recent years, the Jamstack methodology for building websites has become increasingly popular. Performance, scalable, and secure, it‚Äôs easy to see why it‚Äôs becoming an attractive way to build websites for developers.
GatsbyJS is ‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Kinda silly sounding, isn‚Äôt it? CSS database queries. But, hey, CSS is capable of talking to other languages in the sense that it can set the values of things that they can read. Plus, CSS can request other files, and ‚Ä¶
CSS Database Queries? Sure We Can! originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Database Queries? Sure We Can!

articles.author: Daniel Yuschick
articles.description:
Let‚Äôs face it: building an AA or AAA-accessible product can be quite daunting. Luckily, having an accessible product isn‚Äôt all-or-nothing. Even seemingly small improvements can have nice quality of life benefits for many people.
In that spirit, here are five ‚Ä¶
5 Accessibility Quick Wins You Can Implement Today originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: 5 Accessibility Quick Wins You Can Implement Today

Complaining on

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
I linked to Jay‚Äôs front-end predictions last year and I think they panned out pretty well. I think he‚Äôs got a bit of a knack for that wide-scope look at front-end, including tooling and architecture, as well as browser tech. ‚Ä¶

articles.description: As a design community, we all can‚Äôt be silent in these times.
